@mdavidallen I think this coincided directly with MBAs and non-hackers suddenly having the desire and the ability to create tech, ie, many who would have gone to wall street in the 80s joined tech for the promise of big bux without any of the cultural parts of hacker culturr
@andest01 But yes, strongly agree with the idea that almost no one is excited to see a new thing until they see someone else excited to see it, if that makes sense.

@andest01 I was convinced you could get close to solving this with really slow transition animations that ‚Äúexplain‚Äù what is happening, and having the talent toggle back and forth between ‚Äúwhat you know‚Äù and a new view, just needs smart & difficult anchoring and tight tech/editorial pairing
Have been thinking a lot about what technology looks like when consent is elevated over scale since reading this paper from August https://t.co/JQtJjWjvBB https://t.co/vsrflHNhiO

Imagine a world where Facebook made product decisions by consensus? Instead of contemptuously manipulating its users like a science experiment? Facebook is really upset about the idea of having to ask you for permission.

One thing that we never talk much about in tech is consent. Scale and consent are often mutually exclusive. It is extraordinarily difficult to build moral products at scale because of this. https://t.co/Dw5aPSWvtR

Up until this point I had always, I suppose naively, treated folks like Adam as well-meaning people in a difficult situation. Obviously I was wrong. To work at Facebook in 2020 is a wholehearted endorsement of the darkest and most reprehensible behaviors in tech. https://t.co/k4V8fi1yVK
